div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE No. 7,239 ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orient" will leave Suez about January 26
R.M.S "Orontes" will leave Suez about February 9.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Port Said about January 15
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Port Said about January 29
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-13-905

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Chesire 5,775 tons, leaves about January 18.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,636 tons, leaves about February 1.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, leaves about January 22.
S.S. Herfefordshire 7,183 tons leaves about February 5.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Menepthah now on the berth, will sail on or about Thursday, January 18, to be followed by S.S. Seti.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. Martaban 7100 Tons will leave PORT SAID about Jan. 25 for Liverpool.
S.S. Amarapoora 6600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about Feb. 1 for Liverpool.
S.S. Irrawaddy 7300 Tons will leave PORT SAID about Feb. 15 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Naxos Jan. 15 from Antwerp bound for Beyrouth.
S.S. Argos Jan. 16 from Antwerp bound for Hamburg.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: CAPITAL: L. 3,000,000. RESERVE (ENVIRON) : L. 1,340,000.
Gouverneur: Sir ELWIN PALMER, K.C.B., K.C.M.G.

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah. Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street).

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-13-905

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.
div.p: BRANCHES: London 55-56 Bishops gate-street Within-Alexandria, Cairo, Constantinople, Smyrna, At Candia and throughout Greece.

The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece,
etc. Interest, on cash deposits: 3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0
per ann. for 6 months ; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months ; 5 0/0 per
ann. for 3 years and over. Savings Bank Branch receives de-
posits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 30 to P.T. 10,000. 23538-19-1.905

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 3, 17 and 31 January, 4 p.m.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 25 December, 8 and 22 January, 4 p.m.

To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 October, 8 Nov., 8 Dec.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 19 Oct, 3, 19 Nov., 19 Dec 4 p.m.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Oct., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. Shipyard for construction of sternwheel steamers, barges, stream, motor launches, etc. Contractors for supply and erection of all classes of machinery, buildings, irrigation pumps, etc.
SOLE AGENTS FOR Dudbridges Oil Engines from 1 to 35 B.H.P. as supplied to Sudan Government. Seamless Steel Boat Co., Ltd. etc., etc.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh-Alexandria
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
G. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.

div.p: M. H. DEMIRGIAN BEY, General Agent for this important House, warns the public to beware of Imitations, and to examine the labels, corks, and capsules.
The principal importers of this well-known Brand are
At Alexandria: MM. G. Attard & Co. Christo C. Solea, Costi H. Georgiou, N. Pappa, A. & G. Monferato, John B. Caffari, Frangini Mitzos & Co. Cokinos Freres, P, J. Zombos.

Where customers will find the genuine MARTELLI, which cannot be sold below the minimum price given below for each quality:
* 35/- per case or P.T. 170.5.
VO 53/- per case or P.T. 256.
All so-called MARTELL Cognacs sold below these prices cannot be genuine.

div.head: DEATH
div.p: AUSTICK - At Zagazig, on the 13gh inst., Arthur George Austick, eldest son of the late A.G. Austick, Port Tewflk, aged 23.

div.head: MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1906.
THE ELECTION.
div.p: The extraordinary defeat of the ex-Prime Minister at Manchester and the recent great Liberal gains look as though the polling is going strong against the Unionists. But it must be remembered that the Liberal- Labour party has a great many victories yet to win, for in order to gain a majority of fifty over Unionists and Nationalists, the party must perform the almost superhuman feat of capturing no fewer than 172 seats, counting 341 votes on a division. This, extravagant as it appears, is actually forty votes lower than the forecast of Mr. W. T. Stead, who predicted a turnover of 192 seats, counting 384 on a division. We now trace the fl act nation in the voting since the General Election of 1895 :
In 1895 Unionist polling was 12 percent higher than Anti Unionist.
In 1895-1909 Unionist polling was 3-1/2 percent. lower than Anti-Unionist.
In 1900 Unionist polling was 12 percent. higher than Anti-Unionist.

In 1903-1905 Unionist polling was 12 percent lower than Anti-Unionist From this table it is dear that if by-polling were a direct index to General Election polling —and this is the assumption upon which the hopes of a Liberal-Labour majority have admittedly been founded—the Unionist Government would have been beaten in 1900 by a 3-1/2 percent majority of the electorate. As it was, the 3-1/2 percent, minority was converted into a 12 percent majority—a turnover of 15-1/2 percent, in all. This 15-1/2 percent, in fact, is the figure of discount to be allowed for anti- Ministerial bias. If events follow in 1906 the fairly regular course they have taken since 1895—and there is nothing to show that they will not do so—the 12 per cent by election Unionist minority will be converted into a 8-1/2 percent. General Election Unionist majority. This would give the Unionist party a small majority of perhaps thirty seats in Great Britain only. Assuming that Ireland returns eighty-two Nationalist and twenty-one Unionist members, the Unionist party would be left in a minority in the House of Commons of thirty- one—the Government majority being composed of Liberal, Labour, and Nationalist members.

This calculation opens the way to a number of possibilities, all of uncommon interest. In the first place, the majority of (approximately) thirty-one is the highest majority which Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman can hope for, as attested by Liberal statistics — unless the course of political feeling in the country is to be completely diverted from its accustomed channel. If the Prime Minister can perform -this feat, he may obtain a majority of perhaps sixty members. Will he do so 1 In the light of the events of the last few days there is no warrant for supposing that it is impossible.

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.
div.p: ELECTION CAMPAIGN.
MR. BLAFOUR DEFEATED.
TIDE FLOWING WITH LIBERALS.
London, January 13. The Liberals Messrs. D. F. Goddard and F. T. Cobbold have been elected for Ipswich. The election of the latter constitutes a Liberal gain. (Reuter)

London, January 13. The following Members have been returned unopposed: RiahtHon. James W. Lowther (C.), Penrith. Sir J. Kitson,Bait.(L), Colne. Mr. 8. T Evans L.), Mid Glamorgan. Mr. J. G, Talbot (UA and Sir W. Anson (U), Oxford University. Messrs. Carion (U.) and J. H. M. Campbell (U.), Dublin University. Messrs. 0 Bnen and Roohe(Nationalists), Cork.Messe W.Field (N) And Mannetti (N.), Dublin.Hon.F.W. Lambtou (U.), Durham. _ . . Hitherto 38 Liberals and 12 Unionists have been eleoted. Liberal gains 16. Later. 45 Liberals and 12 Unionists have been returned liberal gains 22. Manchester. E. Mr. Harridge (L.), 6403. Mr. Balfour (C.), 4323. (Reuter)

London, January 13. It is believed that a safe seat has been found for Mr. Balfour at Eccles. Unionist clubs recognize the fact that the tide is Bowing with the Liberals, and are preparing for the worst. Even strong candidates are beginning to quake, knowing that vacillators always follow the lead of previous elections. Liberal headquarters are proportionately jubilant and are confident of a big independent majority (Reuter)

div.head: MOROCCO CONFERENCE
div.p: COUNT TATTENBACH HOPEFUL.

Paris, January 13. Count Tattenbach, German delegate at the Morocco Conference, has passed through Paris on his way to Algesiras. In an interview he expressed the hope that the Conference would have good results. (Havas)
Paris, January 14. Interviewed here, Count Tattenbach said that he expected that the Morocco Conference will last two months. He was convinced that an agreement will be reached. (Reuter)
Algesiras, January 14. The Morocco delegates have arrived. (H)

div.head: FRANCE AND VENEZUELA.
div.p: DIPLOMATIC RUPTURE.
Paris, January 13. Diplomatic relations with Venezuela have been broken off. (Reuter)
New York, January 12. Telegraphic communications with Venezuela are interrupted. (Reuter)

div.head: BANK OF FRANCE NOTES.
div.p: INCREASE OF CIRCULATION.

Paris, January 13. The circulation' of Bank of France notes having reached the maximum, the Government has introduced a bill increasing the circulation by 800,000,000 francs in order to avert the depletion of the metal reserve. (R.)

div.head: STATE OF RUSSIA.
div.p: MASSACRES IN THE CAUCASUS.
St. Petersburg, January 13. Tartars and Armenians in Caucasia continue to burn each other’s villages, massacring the inhabitants and attacking the troops. (Reuter)
Tiflis, January 13. Normal circulation has been re-established on the Trans Caucasian Railways. (Havas)

div.head: NEW ORLEANS COTTON GROWERS.
div.p: FAVOUR HOLDING COTTON.
The New Orleans Convention of Cotton Growers has passed a resolution in favor of holding cotton until a price of 15 cents per pound be reached. (Reuter)

div.head: REPUBLICANS' DUTY
div.p: Paris, January 14. In a speech delivered at the Jardiea, M. Etienne extolled the teachings of Gambetta, which would forever point out to France thé Republican patriotic duty. (Havas)

div.head: C.M.G. FOR MACAULEY BEY.
div.p: London, January 13. Major Macauley has been created Companion of Saint Michael and Saint George on account of services in connection with the Suakin-Berber Railway. (Reuter)

div.head: INTERNATIONAL FOOTBALL.
div.p: London, January 13. Football. Rugby. Wales beat England by 16 to 3. (Reuter)

div.head: REPORTED FUSION OF HAMBURG-AMERIKA AND N.D.L.S.CO
div.p: A report is current in Berlin financial circles which ought to be well informed that further negotiations between the Hamburg- Amerika and North German Lloyd Steamship Companies have brought a fusion of the two undertakings considerably nearer realization. Although the dispute was settled a fortnight ago, further conferences between Herr Ballin and Herr Wiegand took place towards the end of last week, and it is said that the question of amalgamation was discussed in detail.

It is further stated that these two gentlemen drew np the outlines of a definite schema for presentation to the general meeting of their respective companies. It is impossible to obtain definite particulars of what has passed, owing to the fact that both companies persistently refuse all information. It is certain, however, that one or two of the leading financial houses in Berlin have made extensive purchases of the shares of both the Hamburg and the Bremen companies in anticipation of amalgamation, which would probably result in considerable financial gain to the shareholders of both.

It is also stated the contracts which the North German Lloyd recently concluded with the Russian Government for the transport of troops from Vladivostok to Odessa contained a clause providing for the possibility of fusion.

div.head: NAVAL CONTRACTS.
div.p: PORT SAID and SUEZ.

TENDERS are hereby invited for new Contracts for the supply of Fresh Beef, Mutton, Vegetables, Soft; Bread, and Water to His Majesty's Ships at Port Said and Suez, tor twelve months from 1st April 1906.
Each article should be tendered for separately, bat the tenders for all the articles offered by any particular firm must be placid on the same form.

Prices should be quoted in English currency. Forms of Application can be obtained from the Navy Agent, British Consulate, Port Said, to whom tenders should be sent in duplicate, in sealed envelope, in time to be received not later than the 31st January 1906.

The Admiralty reserve the right of rejecting all or any tenders, and of accepting any portion of a tender. (signed) D. A. CAMERON, Navy Agent. British Consulate, Port-Said, 6th January, 1906. 27087*-3-2

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION
div.p: COAL.

TENDERS will be received at the British Army Head Quarters, Cairo, np till 12 o’clock noon on Thursday, 18th January, 1906, for the supply of 150 tons House Coal, delivered free on Quay at Candia, Crete, not later than 31st January 1906. Forms of Tender and all information may be obtained on application at the British Head Quarters, Cairo, and Alexandria. Envelopes containing Tenders should be addressed “General Officer Commanding, Cairo, and marked on the outside “Tender for Coal, Crete." The General Officer Commanding does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any tender. E. R 0. Ludlow, Lient. Colonel. Commanding Army Service Corps in Egypt. Cairo, 11th January 1906. 27116-8-3

div.head: Egyptian State Railways and Telegraphs.
div.p: NOTICE.

The Egyptian State Railways Administration has the honour to inform the Public that, commencing from 15th January, “Luxe train” No. 81 which leaves Luxor at 6.30 p.m. will be stopped at Guizeh station to set down passengers if due notice is given to the Stationmaster of the station from which such passenger starts. Cairo, 9th January, 1906 J. H. L\ Johnstone, 27130 1 General Manager.
